stories.title: Ask HN: Have you read the Bible in its entirety, and what was your impression?

stories.text: Assume the following hypothetical situation: You discover a blatant GPL infringement in a piece of software. Blatant such that the programmers were so careless and lazy they made nearly no attempts to cover their tracks. However, the offenders are located in a country that is known to be hostile to matters of intellectual property. Is trying to enforce the GPL in such a situation basically impossible?
stories.title: Ask HN: Is GPL enforcement outside the West possible?
Thomas Midgley Jr: The One Man Environmental Disaster
Ukrainian Battle Buggies Are Out to Kill Russian Tanks

stories.text:
Hello Denizens of Hacker News,  a topic that has been on my mind a lot recently is how to effectively manage technical debt.
As a veteran developer who has worked for a variety of companies I have mostly seen tech debt handled poorly, even to the point of developers being penalized by management for not working quickly enough. I wanted to ask… What are the most common types of tech debt you’ve seen in your companies? How do you prioritize dealing with tech debt so that the team stays productive?
stories.title: Ask HN: How to Manage Tech Debt?
Factors to consider when architecting systems that uses third-party systems

stories.text:
I've seen posts about people posting what they were doing about the bar being so low in tech. So I decided to post my own affairs.

I currently have 50 roles in tech; what I am doing is essentially outsourcing the labor to India, Poland, Nigeria, and Argentina. I am, basically, running an outsourcing company at this stage and have people process and handle requests in those countries and assign engineers. I learned a ton about quality control and am making 7.5M a year. I am able to juggle the work because most of my gigs are in startups and meetings rarely happen so i'm pretty much running on autopilot.
stories.title: Employeed at 50 Companies
